Award.AwardTitle: MRI TRACK I: Acquisition of a Super Resolution Module for Biological and Advanced Materials Imaging

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: Light-based microscopes are indispensable to the advancement of many scientific fields. Lamentably, there is a lower limit to the size of objects that can be observed due to physics of light itself. This barrier impedes investigation of minuscule objects. Fortunately, recent advances have helped overcome this hurdle, yielding “super-resolution” microscopes. The specific super-resolution technology acquired by this award is well-suited for imaging dynamic objects like those in cells as well as nanoparticles created in the laboratory. Projects that will take advantage of the microscope include: material scientists studying assembly of high performance plastic-like materials, cell biologists and biochemists investigating cell components important in Alzheimer’s and genetic tools, and microbiologists that examine bacterial community structures involved in infection and plant-soil interactions. Availability of the super-resolution microscope will provide opportunities for training in cutting-edge imaging for faculty and students throughout Mississippi. Emphasis will be placed on involving underserved communities and faculty at small colleges and universities <br/><br/>This proposal requests a Leica Stimulated Emission Depletion 3X super resolution microscopy component. The system enables imaging of nano-scale objects smaller than the diffraction limit of light without the need for specialized fluorophores, intense laser exposure, and heavy computational processing of data. Thus, acquisition of the component will benefit numerous projects at the host institute as well as other academic research in the region. It will integrate with an existing confocal microscope housed and maintained in an imaging core facility on the University of Southern Mississippi Hattiesburg campus. The core is a multi-user facility that provides access, consultation, training, and technical support free of charge to Mississippi academic scientists. The module will support the research and education missions of the core facility along with projects supported by multi-institute consortia aimed at engineering novel spectral properties in organic compounds. Together this makes the system a highly accessible instrument, offering a cutting-edge imaging mode to even the most resource limited researchers, while synergistically empowering statewide programs to advance their research programs and education missions.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Light-based microscopes are indispensable to the advancement of many scientific fields. Lamentably, there is a lower limit to the size of objects that can be observed due to physics of light itself. This barrier impedes investigation of the tiniest of objects, which are important to understand for the study of life and material sciences. Fortunately, recent advances have vaulted over this hurdle, giving scientists the tool of "super-resolution" microscopes. The instrument acquired by this award is a specific type of super-resolution microscope that is well-suited for imaging dynamic objects in motion. This includes parts of cells and nanoparticles created in the laboratory. Due to the numerous uses of such a microscope a diverse group of scientists at the University of Southern Mississippi (USM) came together to request this microscope from the National Science Foundation. 

 

Even though the microscope was installed only five month ago as of this writing, many research projects have already taken advantage of its capabilities. Material scientists studying nanoparticles have used it to see interaction of their particles with cells. Biochemists have used the microscope to study the formation of substances that lead to progression of Alzheimer's. Importantly, access to this advanced microscope has led to initiation of research projects at the host institute, USM, that were not possible before. This is evident from grants submitted by faculty that feature the microscope?s capabilities in experimental plans. These projects include studying how ticks feed, and the behavior of immune cells that contribute to allergic reaction. Additional ongoing projects that would not otherwise be possible without the microscope are the study of polymer diffusion, study morphologies of imprinted polymers on electrodes, doping of conjugated polymers, and structures formed by coronaviruses like SARS-CoV-2 inside cells. 

 

In addition to the benefit to research at the host institute, faculty at other universities and colleges in the state have also used the microscope. Chemists from the University of Mississippi have collaborated with cell biologists at USM to study cell-chemical interactions. Access to the microscope's capabilities also benefited a project at the Mississippi University for Women being featured in a grant application from a faculty at this school. Further benefit to research programs are expected. The microscope is advertised as a resource through the two largest research consortiums in the state. The first is the MS INBRE network, a NIH funded program that provides infrastructure for scientific research in Mississippi. Through this program free access is offered to all researchers either through training so researchers can use the microscope themselves or as a service where MS INBRE personnel will take pictures of samples as a service. The other project is the Center for Emergent Optoelectronics (CEMOS), an EPSCoR track I project that brings together Mississippi's most capable researchers for a collaborative project. Thus by advertising through both program the full gamut of researchers, both those at small schools and large, research active schools will be reached and become potential users.

 

Access to the microscope also offers training opportunity for students in Mississippi. Shortly after installation of the microscope, faculty held workshops for training in super resolution as well as other microscope technologies. The workshop had over 50 attendees, including students from HBCUs, such Jackson State University and Alcorn State University. In addition to providing training opportunities, the microscope was also featured on the local news for counties around USM. Communication with the public that USM possesses cutting edge technology, greatly benefits USM with recruiting the best local students.
